item.title: Gold-Medal-Level Olympiad Geometry Solving with Efficient Heuristic Auxiliary Constructions
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Automated theorem proving, Euclidean geometry, Auxiliary constructions, IMO-30 benchmark, HAGeo

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of automated theorem proving in Euclidean geometry, focusing on problems at the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) level. The authors introduce a CPU-based method that avoids neural network inference, emphasizing efficiency and accessibility. Initially, a simple random strategy for inserting auxiliary points demonstrates silver-medal level human performance on the IMO-30 benchmark. Enhancing this approach, the HAGeo method employs heuristic techniques for auxiliary construction addition in geometric deduction, successfully solving 28 of 30 problems on the IMO-30 benchmark, achieving gold-medal level results and outperforming the neural network-based AlphaGeometry system significantly. To provide a more rigorous and extensive evaluation, the authors develop a new benchmark called HAGeo-409, which includes 409 geometry problems with difficulty levels assessed by humans. This benchmark offers greater difficulty and precision compared to the widely used IMO-30, establishing a higher standard for automated geometry theorem proving research and evaluation. The work demonstrates that heuristic-based auxiliary constructions can effectively advance the state of the art in automated geometric reasoning without reliance on neural networks.
arXiv:2512.00097v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Automated theorem proving in Euclidean geometry, particularly for International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) level problems, remains a major challenge and an important research focus in Artificial Intelligence. In this paper, we present a highly efficient method for geometry theorem proving that runs entirely on CPUs without relying on neural network-based inference. Our initial study shows that a simple random strategy for adding auxiliary points can achieve silver-medal level human performance on IMO. Building on this, we propose HAGeo, a Heuristic-based method for adding Auxiliary constructions in Geometric deduction that solves 28 of 30 problems on the IMO-30 benchmark, achieving gold-medal level performance and surpassing AlphaGeometry, a competitive neural network-based approach, by a notable margin. To evaluate our method and existing approaches more comprehensively, we further construct HAGeo-409, a benchmark consisting of 409 geometry problems with human-assessed difficulty levels. Compared with the widely used IMO-30, our benchmark poses greater challenges and provides a more precise evaluation, setting a higher bar for geometry theorem proving.

item.title: Chunking Strategies for Multimodal AI Systems
item.content:encoded:
multimodal chunking, segmentation strategies, cross-modal alignment, taxonomy, AI systems

Summary:

This article presents a comprehensive survey of multimodal chunking strategies aimed at improving the development of effective and efficient AI systems across various data modalities—text, images, audio, video, and cross-modal inputs. It offers a detailed taxonomy and technical analysis of chunking techniques specific to each modality, including fixed-size token windowing for text, object-centric visual chunking for images, silence-based segmentation in audio, and scene detection in videos. The paper evaluates classical and modern approaches in terms of methodology, available supporting tools such as LangChain, Detectron2, and PySceneDetect, and highlights the benefits and challenges, particularly focusing on the trade-offs between granularity and context as well as issues around multimodal alignment. The survey further explores emerging cross-modal chunking methods that emphasize maintaining alignment and semantic consistency across different data types. Comparative insights are provided to understand the strengths and limitations of these strategies. Finally, the work identifies open problems like asynchronous information density and noisy alignment signals, suggesting future research directions centered on adaptive, learning-based, and task-specific chunking strategies to enhance robustness, scalability, and generative coherence in real-world multimodal AI applications.
arXiv:2512.00185v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Our goal is to consolidate the landscape of multimodal chunking strategies, providing researchers and practitioners with a technical foundation and design space for developing more effective and efficient multimodal AI systems. This survey paves the way for innovations in robust chunking pipelines that scale with modality complexity, enhance processing accuracy, and improve generative coherence in real-world applications. This survey provides a comprehensive taxonomy and technical analysis of chunking strategies tailored for each modality: text, images, audio, video, and cross-modal data. We examine classical and modern approaches such as fixed-size token windowing, recursive text splitting, object-centric visual chunking, silence-based audio segmentation, and scene detection in videos. Each approach is analyzed in terms of its underlying methodology, supporting tools (e.g., LangChain, Detectron2, PySceneDetect), benefits, and challenges, particularly those related to granularity-context trade-offs and multimodal alignment. Furthermore, we explore emerging cross-modal chunking strategies that aim to preserve alignment and semantic consistency across disparate data types [4]. We also include comparative insights, highlight open problems such as asynchronous information density and noisy alignment signals, and identify opportunities for future research in adaptive, learning-based, and task-specific chunking.

item.title: A Rosetta Stone for AI Benchmarks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI benchmarks, statistical framework, model capabilities, progress measurement, algorithmic efficiency

Summary:

This article presents a statistical framework designed to unify various AI benchmarks onto a single numerical scale, effectively acting as a "Rosetta Stone" for comparing AI model capabilities and benchmark difficulties across different times and models. Unlike traditional benchmarks that saturate quickly, this framework enables the study of long-run trends in AI progress without relying on assumptions about how capabilities change over time or with training compute. The authors demonstrate three key applications: First, the framework measures the speed of AI progress over time and enables forecasting of future capabilities. Second, it estimates the rate of improvement in algorithmic efficiency, revealing rates that are higher but broadly align with previous research. Third, the approach detects rapid accelerations in AI progress, offering insights into periods of unusually fast development. Overall, this framework provides researchers with a robust tool to analyze AI development trends, forecast future capabilities more reliably, and identify shifts in progress speed that might otherwise be obscured by the limitations of individual benchmarks.
arXiv:2512.00193v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Most AI benchmarks saturate within years or even months after they are introduced, making it hard to study long-run trends in AI capabilities. To address this challenge, we build a statistical framework that stitches benchmarks together, putting model capabilities and benchmark difficulties on a single numerical scale. This acts as a "Rosetta Stone", allowing us to compare models across a wide range of abilities and time, even if they are not evaluated on the same benchmarks. Moreover, this works without assuming how capabilities evolve across time or with training compute. We demonstrate three applications of this framework. First, we use it to measure the speed of AI progress over time, and to forecast future AI capabilities. Second, we estimate the rate of improvements in algorithmic efficiency, finding estimates that are higher, but broadly consistent with prior work. Finally, we find that our approach can be used to detect rapid accelerations in AI progress.

item.title: Reasoning Under Pressure: How do Training Incentives Influence Chain-of-Thought Monitorability?
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI safety, chain of thought, monitorability, training incentives, adversarial optimization

Summary: The paper explores the concept of monitorability in AI systems that generate reasoning in natural language, specifically focusing on their chain of thought (CoT) outputs. The authors investigate whether the reasoning produced by these systems accurately reflects the underlying cognitive processes, which is crucial for detecting harmful or undesirable behaviors. They examine the impact of various training incentives—such as length penalties, KL regularization, and adversarial optimization—on the ability to monitor the AI's reasoning. A novel methodology is introduced to measure monitorability by evaluating if a monitoring system can predict a key latent variable using the model's CoT. Results show that commonly used incentives like length penalties and KL regularization do not have consistent effects on monitorability when model accuracy is held constant. However, adversarial optimization, which penalizes the monitor’s accuracy, significantly degrades monitor performance. Interestingly, directly optimizing for monitorability does not consistently improve it. The study provides important insights into the relationship between training methods and the transparency of AI reasoning, contributing to safer AI system designs. The authors have made their code publicly available for further research and validation.
arXiv:2512.00218v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: AI systems that output their reasoning in natural language offer an opportunity for safety -- we can \emph{monitor} their chain of thought (CoT) for undesirable reasoning, such as the pursuit of harmful objectives. However, the extent to which CoT faithfully reflects the underlying reasoning process, and hence the extent to which it can be usefully monitored, may be influenced by certain aspects of training. We investigate how different \emph{training incentives}, applied to a reasoning model, affect its monitorability. We introduce a novel methodology for measuring monitorability according to whether a monitor can predict a key latent variable using the model's reasoning. When controlling for accuracy, we do not find evidence for consistent effects from commonly used incentives (length penalties and KL regularisation), but we find that adversarial optimisation (penalising monitor accuracy) degrades monitor performance, while direct optimisation for monitorability does not reliably lead to improvements. Our code is available at https://github.com/QiyaoWei/reasoning-under-pressure.

item.title: Trification: A Comprehensive Tree-based Strategy Planner and Structural Verification for Fact-Checking
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: automated fact-checking, claim verification, dependency graph, multi-agent system, verification strategy

Summary:

1. The rapid spread of false information online necessitates the development of automated fact-checking systems to maintain the integrity of media ecosystems.

2. Existing fact-checking methods leverage large language model (LLM)-based multi-agent systems that decompose claims into simpler sub-tasks, but they face two main issues: incomplete verification of all claim components and the absence of a structured framework to logically combine sub-task results.

3. The proposed framework, Trification, addresses these issues by first generating a comprehensive set of verification actions that ensure all parts of a claim are verified.

4. These verification actions are then organized into a dependency graph, which models the logical relationships and interactions between the different verification steps.

5. The dependency graph is dynamically adaptable, allowing the system to modify its verification strategy based on intermediate results.

6. Experiments on two challenging benchmarks show that Trification significantly improves fact-checking accuracy over previous state-of-the-art automated fact-checking systems.

7. This novel structured and dynamic approach represents an advancement in automated fact-checking, enhancing both coverage and logical reasoning within the verification process.
arXiv:2512.00267v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Technological advancement allows information to be shared in just a single click, which has enabled the rapid spread of false information. This makes automated fact-checking system necessary to ensure the safety and integrity of our online media ecosystem. Previous methods have demonstrated the effectiveness of decomposing the claim into simpler sub-tasks and utilizing LLM-based multi agent system to execute them. However, those models faces two limitations: they often fail to verify every component in the claim and lack of structured framework to logically connect the results of sub-tasks for a final prediction. In this work, we propose a novel automated fact-checking framework called Trification. Our framework begins by generating a comprehensive set of verification actions to ensure complete coverage of the claim. It then structured these actions into a dependency graph to model the logical interaction between actions. Furthermore, the graph can be dynamically modified, allowing the system to adapt its verification strategy. Experimental results on two challenging benchmarks demonstrate that our framework significantly enhances fact-checking accuracy, thereby advancing current state-of-the-art in automated fact-checking system.

item.title: ChartPoint: Guiding MLLMs with Grounding Reflection for Chart Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Multimodal Large Language Models, chart comprehension, PointCoT, visual grounding, ChartPoint-SFT-62k

Summary:

The paper addresses the limitations of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in chart comprehension, specifically their reliance on OCR-extracted content that leads to numerical hallucinations when textual annotations in charts are sparse. It identifies that MLLMs struggle with grounding their reasoning in visual elements and proportional relationships within charts, as they fail to localize key positions necessary for accurate reasoning. To overcome this, the authors propose PointCoT, a method that incorporates reflective interaction into chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning by prompting MLLMs to generate bounding boxes around chart elements and re-render charts based on those annotations. This approach links textual reasoning steps directly with visual regions in the chart, enhancing model grounding. Additionally, the paper introduces ChartPoint-SFT-62k, an automated dataset comprising 19.2K high-quality chart samples annotated with step-by-step CoT reasoning, bounding boxes, and re-rendered visuals, aimed at training and evaluating models effectively. Using this data, two instruction-tuned models, ChartPointQ2 and ChartPointQ2.5, are developed, which demonstrate superior performance over existing state-of-the-art models on multiple chart understanding benchmarks, achieving a notable +5.04% improvement on the ChartBench benchmark.
arXiv:2512.00305v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have emerged as powerful tools for chart comprehension. However, they heavily rely on extracted content via OCR, which leads to numerical hallucinations when chart textual annotations are sparse. While existing methods focus on scaling instructions, they fail to address the fundamental challenge, i.e., reasoning with visual perception. In this paper, we identify a critical observation: MLLMs exhibit weak grounding in chart elements and proportional relationships, as evidenced by their inability to localize key positions to match their reasoning. To bridge this gap, we propose PointCoT, which integrates reflective interaction into chain-of-thought reasoning in charts. By prompting MLLMs to generate bounding boxes and re-render charts based on location annotations, we establish connections between textual reasoning steps and visual grounding regions. We further introduce an automated pipeline to construct ChartPoint-SFT-62k, a dataset featuring 19.2K high-quality chart samples with step-by-step CoT, bounding box, and re-rendered visualizations. Leveraging this data, we develop two instruction-tuned models, ChartPointQ2 and ChartPointQ2.5, which outperform state-of-the-art across several chart benchmarks, e.g., +5.04\% on ChartBench.

item.title: RL-Struct: A Lightweight Reinforcement Learning Framework for Reliable Structured Output in LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Structure Gap, Reinforcement Learning, JSON validity, Gradient Regularized Policy Optimization

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge known as the "Structure Gap" in integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with automated software systems, where probabilistic token generation clashes with the deterministic demands of structured data formats like JSON and XML. Traditional Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and constrained decoding techniques struggle either by failing to enforce strict syntactic constraints or by incurring high inference latency. To overcome these limitations, the authors propose a lightweight Reinforcement Learning (RL) framework featuring a novel Multi-dimensional Reward Function that breaks down structured output generation into hierarchical constraints: structural integrity, format correctness, content accuracy, and validity. They employ Gradient Regularized Policy Optimization (GRPO), which avoids the need for a separate critic network and reduces VRAM usage by 40% compared to PPO. The approach is validated on tasks such as recipe generation and GSM8K-JSON structured math reasoning, achieving 89.7% structural accuracy and 92.1% JSON validity, outperforming zero-shot GPT-3.5 and SFT on LLaMA-3-8B models. Analysis of training dynamics reveals a self-paced curriculum where the model first masters syntax before improving semantic accuracy. The trained model has been made publicly available for use.
arXiv:2512.00319v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in natural language generation and reasoning. However, their integration into automated software ecosystems is often hindered by the "Structure Gap" - the inherent tension between the probabilistic nature of token generation and the deterministic requirements of structured data formats (e.g., JSON, XML). Traditional Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) often fails to enforce strict syntactic constraints, leading to "hallucinated" keys or malformed structures, while constrained decoding methods impose significant inference latency. In this paper, we propose a lightweight, efficient Reinforcement Learning (RL) framework to bridge this gap. We introduce a novel Multi-dimensional Reward Function that decomposes the structured output task into a hierarchy of constraints: structural integrity, format correctness, content accuracy, and validity. Leveraging Gradient Regularized Policy Optimization (GRPO), we enable the model to internalize these constraints without the need for a separate critic network, reducing peak VRAM usage by 40% compared to PPO. We validate our approach on multiple tasks, including complex recipe generation and structured math reasoning (GSM8K-JSON). Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves 89.7% structural accuracy and 92.1% JSON validity, significantly outperforming both zero-shot baselines (e.g., GPT-3.5) and SFT on larger models like LLaMA-3-8B. Furthermore, we provide a detailed analysis of training dynamics, revealing a distinct self-paced curriculum where the model sequentially acquires syntactic proficiency before semantic accuracy. Our model is publicly available at https://huggingface.co/Freakz3z/Qwen-JSON.

item.title: CogEvo-Edu: Cognitive Evolution Educational Multi-Agent Collaborative System
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, educational multi-agent system, digital signal processing, student modeling, hierarchical control

Summary: Large language models (LLMs) are commonly used as conversational tutors in STEM education, but most systems rely on a single LLM with a static retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline, which is insufficient for complex domains like digital signal processing (DSP). The paper argues for coupling retrieval, memory, and control as a unified cognitive evolution process to better adapt to student needs. CogEvo-Edu, a hierarchical educational multi-agent system, is proposed, consisting of three layers: Cognitive Perception Layer (CPL), Knowledge Evolution Layer (KEL), and Meta-Control Layer (MCL). CPL maintains dual memories and uses confidence-weighted consolidation to create accurate, self-correcting student profiles even under limited contextual information. KEL manages knowledge by assigning spatiotemporal values to chunks, enabling activation, semantic compression, and forgetting mechanisms. MCL treats tutoring as hierarchical sequential decision making, orchestrating specialized agents and jointly tuning CPL and KEL parameters via a dual inner-outer loop. To evaluate the system, a new benchmark named DSP-EduBench was introduced, featuring diverse resources, simulated student profiles, and long-term interaction scripts specifically for DSP tutoring. Empirical results show that CogEvo-Edu significantly outperforms static RAG, simple memory, and single-agent baselines by improving overall scores and all six evaluation metrics, demonstrating the advantages of jointly evolving student models, knowledge bases, and teaching policies.
arXiv:2512.00331v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed as conversational tutors in STEM education, yet most systems still rely on a single LLM with a static retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline over course materials. This design struggles in complex domains such as digital signal processing (DSP), where tutors must maintain coherent long-term student models, manage heterogeneous knowledge bases, and adapt teaching strategies over extended interactions. We argue that retrieval, memory, and control should be treated as a coupled cognitive evolution process. We instantiate this view in CogEvo-Edu, a hierarchical educational multi-agent system comprising a Cognitive Perception Layer (CPL), a Knowledge Evolution Layer (KEL), and a Meta-Control Layer (MCL). CPL maintains dual memories and performs confidence-weighted consolidation to build structured, self-correcting student profiles under limited context. KEL assigns each knowledge chunk a spatiotemporal value that drives activation, semantic compression, and forgetting. MCL formulates tutoring as hierarchical sequential decision making, orchestrating specialized agents and jointly adapting CPL/KEL hyperparameters via a dual inner--outer loop. To evaluate CogEvo-Edu, we construct DSP-EduBench, a vertical benchmark for DSP tutoring with heterogeneous resources, simulated student profiles, and long-horizon interaction scripts. Using a three-model LLM-as-a-Judge ensemble, CogEvo-Edu raises the overall score from 5.32 to 9.23 and improves all six indicators over static RAG, simple memory, and a single-agent variant, demonstrating the value of jointly evolving student profiles, knowledge bases, and teaching policies.

item.title: Echo-N1: Affective RL Frontier
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: RL, personalized conversation, emotional intelligence, user personality inference, Echo-N1

Summary:
1. The paper critiques existing reinforcement learning (RL) approaches in large language models (LLMs), highlighting their focus on objective tasks like math and code while neglecting subjective, emotionally nuanced conversation that defines human intelligence.
2. It posits that personalized, emotionally grounded dialogue, once thought unsuitable for conventional RL, is in fact a solvable and transformative problem within RL frameworks.
3. The authors propose a novel RL framework that dynamically infers the user's personality during interaction and optimizes the model's behavior accordingly to better align with personalized conversational preferences.
4. Contrary to prior beliefs that RL struggles in non-verifiable, subjective settings, the method demonstrates consistent, robust, and significant improvements in humanlike conversational quality.
5. A new dynamic emotional intelligence evaluation suite is introduced to quantitatively measure these conversational gains.
6. The developed model, Echo-N1, significantly outperforms its base version and even surpasses the proprietary Doubao 1.5 Character model.
7. This work establishes a pioneering direction for RL research focused on optimizing models for deeply subjective, emotionally rich, and personality-sensitive human conversations.
arXiv:2512.00344v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The LLM field has spent a year perfecting RL for tasks machines already excel at, math, code, and deterministic reasoning, while completely sidestepping the domain that actually defines human intelligence: subjective, emotionally grounded, personality sensitive conversation. This space has often been regarded as inherently subjective and challenging to formalize, making it appear unsuitable for conventional RL pipelines. We show that it is not only possible and it is a solvable and transformative RL problem. We propose the first framework that infers user personality on the fly and optimizes model behavior toward personalized conversational preferences. Contrary to the widespread belief that RL collapses in non-verifiable settings, our method produces consistent, robust, and dramatic improvements in humanlike interaction quality. We also introduce the first dynamic emotional intelligence evaluation suite to quantify these gains. Our model, which is introduced as Echo-N1, behaves far above its base version and outperforming the proprietary Doubao 1.5 Character. This work establishes a new frontier for RL: optimizing models for the deeply subjective, deeply human dimensions of conversation.

item.title: Debate with Images: Detecting Deceptive Behaviors in Multimodal Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Deception, Multimodal, Large Language Models, Safety Risks, Benchmark

Summary: The paper addresses the rising safety risks associated with deception in frontier AI systems, particularly in multimodal large language models (LLMs). Unlike hallucinations, which are errors from lack of knowledge, deception involves models intentionally misleading users through sophisticated reasoning and insincere responses. As AI capabilities improve, deceptive behavior has extended beyond text into multimodal contexts, increasing potential harm. Current research primarily focuses on text-based deception, leaving multimodal deception risks largely unexplored. To fill this gap, the authors introduce MM-DeceptionBench, the first benchmark designed to systematically evaluate deception across combined visual and textual inputs. The benchmark categorizes six types of deceptive strategies, revealing how models manipulate users using cross-modal information. Detecting multimodal deception is challenging due to the hidden, ambiguous, and complex nature of visual-semantic interactions, rendering traditional monitoring methods ineffective. To address this, the paper proposes a novel "debate with images" multi-agent framework that forces models to substantiate claims with visual evidence, thereby enhancing detection. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach significantly improves alignment with human judgments, increasing Cohen's kappa by 1.5 times and accuracy by 1.25 times on GPT-4o, marking a substantial advance in mitigating multimodal deception in AI systems.
arXiv:2512.00349v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Are frontier AI systems becoming more capable? Certainly. Yet such progress is not an unalloyed blessing but rather a Trojan horse: behind their performance leaps lie more insidious and destructive safety risks, namely deception. Unlike hallucination, which arises from insufficient capability and leads to mistakes, deception represents a deeper threat in which models deliberately mislead users through complex reasoning and insincere responses. As system capabilities advance, deceptive behaviours have spread from textual to multimodal settings, amplifying their potential harm. First and foremost, how can we monitor these covert multimodal deceptive behaviors? Nevertheless, current research remains almost entirely confined to text, leaving the deceptive risks of multimodal large language models unexplored. In this work, we systematically reveal and quantify multimodal deception risks, introducing MM-DeceptionBench, the first benchmark explicitly designed to evaluate multimodal deception. Covering six categories of deception, MM-DeceptionBench characterizes how models strategically manipulate and mislead through combined visual and textual modalities. On the other hand, multimodal deception evaluation is almost a blind spot in existing methods. Its stealth, compounded by visual-semantic ambiguity and the complexity of cross-modal reasoning, renders action monitoring and chain-of-thought monitoring largely ineffective. To tackle this challenge, we propose debate with images, a novel multi-agent debate monitor framework. By compelling models to ground their claims in visual evidence, this method substantially improves the detectability of deceptive strategies. Experiments show that it consistently increases agreement with human judgements across all tested models, boosting Cohen's kappa by 1.5x and accuracy by 1.25x on GPT-4o.

item.title: GreenPlanner: Practical Floorplan Layout Generation via an Energy-Aware and Function-Feasible Generative Framework
item.content:encoded:
Design evaluation, energy performance, floorplan generation, constraint satisfaction, architectural design automation

Summary: This paper introduces GreenPlanner, a novel generative framework aimed at automating the design of building floorplans while ensuring energy efficiency and spatial-functional compliance. The approach addresses the shortcomings of existing methods that generate visually appealing layouts but often violate critical constraints, leading to invalid designs. GreenPlanner integrates a comprehensive Design Feasibility Dataset labeled with constraint priors, enabling the system to learn essential design rules. It features a Practical Design Evaluator (PDE) capable of rapidly predicting energy performance and checking spatial-functional validity, achieving an evaluation speed increase of over 100,000 times with more than 99% accuracy. By leveraging PDE for filtering, the authors constructed the Green Plan Dataset (GreenPD), which pairs user requirements with regulation-compliant layouts to train the GreenFlow generator. This generator, guided by PDE feedback, produces controllable and regulation-aware floorplans that meet energy and functional constraints effectively. Experimental results demonstrate that GreenPlanner not only eliminates invalid design samples but also enhances professional architectural design efficiency by 87%, presenting a significant advancement in scalable, cost-effective, and automated building design processes.
arXiv:2512.00406v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Building design directly affects human well-being and carbon emissions, yet generating spatial-functional and energy-compliant floorplans remains manual, costly, and non-scalable. Existing methods produce visually plausible layouts but frequently violate key constraints, yielding invalid results due to the absence of automated evaluation. We present GreenPlanner, an energy- and functionality-aware generative framework that unifies design evaluation and generation. It consists of a labeled Design Feasibility Dataset for learning constraint priors; a fast Practical Design Evaluator (PDE) for predicting energy performance and spatial-functional validity; a Green Plan Dataset (GreenPD) derived from PDE-guided filtering to pair user requirements with regulation-compliant layouts; and a GreenFlow generator trained on GreenPD with PDE feedback for controllable, regulation-aware generation. Experiments show that GreenPlanner accelerates evaluation by over $10^{5}\times$ with $>$99% accuracy, eliminates invalid samples, and boosts design efficiency by 87% over professional architects.

item.title: Mind the data gap: Missingness Still Shapes Large Language Model Prognoses
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: missingness, large language models, healthcare data, zero-shot prediction, model calibration

Summary:

1. The study addresses how data missingness, which often reflects human decisions in contexts like healthcare diagnostics, affects predictive modeling.
2. It focuses on the impact of missingness patterns on the zero-shot predictive performance of various Large Language Models (LLMs).
3. Experiments were conducted using real-world healthcare datasets from Columbia University Medical Center and MIMIC-IV.
4. Results show that incorporating missingness indicators explicitly in prompts can improve or deteriorate zero-shot prediction and calibration, depending on the LLM involved.
5. Larger models tend to benefit from including missingness information, whereas smaller models may experience negative effects.
6. The paper highlights that LLMs might further obscure the influence of missing data, an issue also prevalent in traditional machine learning but often overlooked.
7. The authors advocate for more transparent and systematic evaluation of how representing informative missingness affects downstream model performance, especially in healthcare applications.
arXiv:2512.00479v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Data collection often reflects human decisions. In healthcare, for instance, a referral for a diagnostic test is influenced by the patient's health, their preferences, available resources, and the practitioner's recommendations. Despite the extensive literature on the informativeness of missingness, its implications on the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) have not been studied. Through a series of experiments on data from Columbia University Medical Center, a large urban academic medical center, and MIMIC-IV, we demonstrate that patterns of missingness significantly impact zero-shot predictive performance. Notably, the explicit inclusion of missingness indicators at prompting benefits some while hurting other LLMs' zero-shot predictive performance and calibration, suggesting an inconsistent impact. The proposed aggregated analysis and theoretical insights suggest that larger models benefit from these interventions, while smaller models can be negatively impacted. The LLM paradigm risks obscuring the impact of missingness, often neglected even in conventional ML, even further. We conclude that there is a need for more transparent accounting and systematic evaluation of the impact of representing (informative) missingness on downstream performance.

item.title: Clinical-R1: Empowering Large Language Models for Faithful and Comprehensive Reasoning with Clinical Objective Relative Policy Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Clinical reasoning, reinforcement learning, large language models, multi-objective optimization, verifiable rewards

Summary:

This article addresses the limitations of current post-training reinforcement learning methods for large language models (LLMs), particularly in high-stakes fields like medicine where correctness alone is insufficient. The authors propose Clinical-Objective Relative Policy Optimization (CRPO), a novel, scalable reinforcement learning approach that aligns LLM training with clinical reasoning principles by integrating multi-dimensional objectives such as accuracy, faithfulness, and comprehensiveness. CRPO achieves this through rule-based and verifiable reward signals, eliminating the need for costly human annotations. To validate their approach, the study introduces Clinical-R1-3B, a 3-billion parameter LLM trained using CRPO specifically for clinical reasoning tasks. Experiments conducted across three clinical benchmarks demonstrate that CRPO significantly improves the model’s truthfulness and completeness compared to the prior state-of-the-art method, Grouped Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), while also maintaining or enhancing accuracy levels. This work highlights the potential for multi-objective, verifiable reinforcement learning methods to better align LLM outputs with domain-specific high-stakes requirements, paving the way for safer, more reliable AI applications in healthcare settings and emphasizing scalability in post-training phases.
arXiv:2512.00601v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have shown strong reasoning capabilities through large-scale pretraining and post-training reinforcement learning, demonstrated by DeepSeek-R1. However, current post-training methods, such as Grouped Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), mainly reward correctness, which is not aligned with the multi-dimensional objectives required in high-stakes fields such as medicine, where reasoning must also be faithful and comprehensive. We introduce Clinical-Objective Relative Policy Optimization (CRPO), a scalable, multi-objective, verifiable reinforcement learning method designed to align LLM post-training with clinical reasoning principles. CRPO integrates rule-based and verifiable reward signals that jointly optimize accuracy, faithfulness, and comprehensiveness without relying on human annotation. To demonstrate its effectiveness, we train Clinical-R1-3B, a 3B-parameter model for clinical reasoning. The experiments on three benchmarks demonstrate that our CRPO substantially improves reasoning on truthfulness and completeness over standard GRPO while maintaining comfortable accuracy enhancements. This framework provides a scalable pathway to align LLM reasoning with clinical objectives, enabling safer and more collaborative AI systems for healthcare while also highlighting the potential of multi-objective, verifiable RL methods in post-training scaling of LLMs for medical domains.

item.title: EDIT: Early Diffusion Inference Termination for dLLMs Based on Dynamics of Training Gradients
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Diffusion-based LLMs, Early Diffusion Inference Termination, reasoning stability, LoRA updates, inference efficiency

Summary: This paper introduces EDIT (Early Diffusion Inference Termination), a novel criterion for accelerating inference in diffusion-based large language models (dLLMs) by adaptively stopping the iterative denoising process once sufficient reasoning stability is detected. EDIT leverages metadata captured during supervised fine-tuning (SFT), specifically a reasoning map derived from AdamW-aggregated LoRA updates, which represent learned reasoning pathways typically discarded after training. By monitoring the alignment between token activations and this reasoning map, EDIT calculates alignment scores that convert into a distribution over tokens unmasked at each denoising step. The stopping criterion is based on detecting convergence when the KL divergence between consecutive steps falls below a threshold for these visible tokens. Experimentally, EDIT reduces the number of diffusion steps required by 11.8% to 68.3%, maintaining or improving accuracy across various reasoning benchmarks. This approach adds minimal storage overhead (~0.02%, or 1.5-2 MB for QKV modules across 32 blocks in an 8 GB model). By utilizing training-gradient dynamics as a rich source of optimization metadata, the work suggests a promising new direction for improving dLLM inference time and cost efficiency without compromising output quality.
arXiv:2512.00670v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Diffusion-based large language models (dLLMs) refine token generations through iterative denoising, but answers often stabilize before all steps complete. We propose EDIT (Early Diffusion Inference Termination), an inference-time criterion that adaptively stops denoising once sufficient reasoning stability relative to training-time reasoning is detected. EDIT monitors the alignment between token activations and a reasoning map derived from AdamW-aggregated LoRA updates captured during supervised fine-tuning (SFT). During training, optimization dynamics generate rich metadata about parameter importance that in prior methods is typically discarded upon model release. We preserve this information as a compact representation of learned reasoning pathways. During inference, alignment scores are converted to a distribution over the tokens already unmasked at the current denoising step, and convergence is detected when KL divergence between consecutive steps falls below a threshold on the matched unmasked (visible) tokens. Across reasoning benchmarks, EDIT reduces diffusion steps by 11.8% to 68.3% while preserving or improving accuracy in most settings, with approximately 0.02% storage overhead (about 1.5-2 MB for all QKV modules across 32 blocks in an 8 GB model). By utilizing training-gradient dynamics, our work opens a new research direction for reducing dLLM inference time and cost.

item.title: Model of human cognition
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, explainability, neuro-theoretical framework, cognitive processes, artificial intelligence

Summary: The article addresses key limitations in the current development of large language models (LLMs), notably their lack of explainability, absence of a unifying theoretical foundation, and high operational costs. It introduces a novel neuro-theoretical framework designed to explain the emergence of intelligence in artificial systems. This framework aims to be functionally robust while maintaining biological plausibility, bridging the gap between neuroscience and AI. The proposed model offers theoretical insights into complex cognitive processes including decision-making and problem solving, thereby providing a deeper understanding of how intelligence can arise. Additionally, the framework enables a computationally efficient methodology for building artificial intelligence systems that are both explainable and generalizable. This approach promises to reduce the operational costs commonly associated with training and deploying large language models. Overall, the work contributes to advancing AI by proposing a unified theoretical perspective that supports the creation of more transparent, efficient, and biologically inspired intelligent systems.
arXiv:2512.00683v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The development of large language models (LLMs) is limited by a lack of explainability, the absence of a unifying theory, and prohibitive operational costs. We propose a neuro-theoretical framework for the emergence of intelligence in systems that is both functionally robust and biologically plausible. The model provides theoretical insights into cognitive processes such as decision-making and problem solving, and a computationally efficient approach for the creation of explainable and generalizable artificial intelligence.

item.title: When Human Preferences Flip: An Instance-Dependent Robust Loss for RLHF
item.content:encoded:
Flipping-Aware Direct Preference Optimization, Preference Flipping, Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback, Bradley-Terry Model, Dataset Quality

Summary:

This paper addresses the problem of preference flipping in human feedback datasets, which negatively impacts the quality of data annotation crucial for aligning large language models (LLMs). Preference flipping refers to the inconsistency where human annotators reverse their preferences due to external factors, corrupting the feedback data. To tackle this, the authors propose Flipping-Aware Direct Preference Optimization (FA-DPO), an algorithm designed to be robust to such flipping within the Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback (RLHF) framework. The approach models human intention and the flip mechanism as two separate stages and incorporates an instance-dependent flipping probability grounded in the Bradley-Terry (BT) model to capture uncertainty in judgments. By leveraging features relevant to preference annotation, the method better identifies and models patterns of preference flipping. The paper also introduces an efficient iterative optimization process that integrates seamlessly with existing RLHF and Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) algorithms. Experimental evaluations demonstrate the effectiveness of FA-DPO across multiple scenarios compared to baseline methods, highlighting its potential to improve dataset quality and alignment robustness in LLM training.
arXiv:2512.00709v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Quality of datasets plays an important role in large language model (LLM) alignment. In collecting human feedback, however, preference flipping is ubiquitous and causes corruption in data annotation; the issue necessitates the alignment algorithms with improved robustness against potential flipped pairs. To this end, this paper introduces a Flipping-Aware Direct Preference Optimization (FA-DPO) algorithm tailored to preference flipping from a reinforcement learning with human feedback (RLHF) perspective. We dissect the inherent human intention model and the preference flipping mechanism introduced by external factors as two distinct stages; in the latter, we introduce an instance-dependent flipping probability on the basis of the Bradley-Terry (BT) model. Further, by leveraging features relevant to preference annotation, we capture uncertainty in judgments and model preference flipping patterns. In practice, we design a simple yet efficient iterative optimization algorithm compatible with the original RLHF and DPO algorithms. In our experiments, we investigate the instance-dependent preference flipping model under multiple circumstances for evaluation of our proposed method, as well as other baseline methods.

item.title: SpeContext: Enabling Efficient Long-context Reasoning with Speculative Context Sparsity in LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: retrieval algorithms, distilled language model, long-context reasoning, GPU memory management, throughput improvement

Summary:

This paper investigates the alignment between retrieval algorithms and large language models (LLMs), likening it to the process of knowledge distillation within LLMs. By analyzing the shared focus on information between distilled language models (DLMs) and original LLMs through an information theory lens, the authors propose a new paradigm that utilizes a DLM as a retrieval algorithm. SpeContext is introduced as an integrated algorithm and system design for enhancing long-context reasoning. At the algorithmic level, SpeContext introduces a lightweight retrieval head that leverages head-level attention weights of the DLM, achieving over 90% reduction in parameters by removing redundancies. On the system side, it employs an asynchronous prefetch dataflow combined with an elastic loading strategy to overlap key-value cache retrieval with ongoing LLM computations. At the compilation level, the work includes the creation of a theoretical memory model and an adaptive memory management system, boosting acceleration by optimizing GPU memory usage. The approach is validated through deployments in both cloud and edge computing environments, showing significant throughput improvements—up to 24.89 times in the cloud and 10.06 times at the edge—over the Huggingface framework, with minimal impact on accuracy. This work effectively advances the balance between accuracy and computational efficiency in LLM retrieval tasks.
arXiv:2512.00722v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this paper, we point out that the objective of the retrieval algorithms is to align with the LLM, which is similar to the objective of knowledge distillation in LLMs. We analyze the similarity in information focus between the distilled language model(DLM) and the original LLM from the perspective of information theory, and thus propose a novel paradigm that leverages a DLM as the retrieval algorithm. Based on the insight, we present SpeContext, an algorithm and system co-design for long-context reasoning. (1) At the algorithm level, SpeContext proposes lightweight retrieval head based on the head-level attention weights of DLM, achieving > 90% parameters reduction by pruning the redundancy. (2) At the system level, SpeContext designs an asynchronous prefetch dataflow via the elastic loading strategy, effectively overlapping KV cache retrieval with the LLM computation. (3) At the compilation level, SpeContext constructs the theoretical memory model and implements an adaptive memory management system to achieve acceleration by maximizing GPU memory utilization. We deploy and evaluate SpeContext in two resourceconstrained environments, cloud and edge. Extensive experiments show that, compared with the Huggingface framework, SpeContext achieves up to 24.89x throughput improvement in cloud and 10.06x speedup in edge with negligible accuracy loss, pushing the Pareto frontier of accuracy and throughput.

item.title: Probing the "Psyche'' of Large Reasoning Models: Understanding Through a Human Lens
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Reasoning Models, Taxonomy, Atomic Reasoning Steps, CAPO, Multi-step Reflection

Summary: This paper introduces a novel taxonomy designed to characterize the atomic reasoning steps of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) by drawing from human mental processes, organizing these steps into five groups and seventeen categories. The taxonomy offers an interdisciplinary framework to better understand the reasoning "psyche" of LRMs. Utilizing this taxonomy, the authors created a comprehensive dataset of 277,534 labeled atomic reasoning steps to perform an in-depth analysis of current LRMs. Their findings show that common post-answer self-monitoring strategies, such as superficial double-checks, seldom result in meaningful improvements or corrections to the reasoning output. As a result, the paper advocates for promoting more rigorous multi-step reflection processes over simple self-monitoring to enhance the effectiveness of model reasoning. To facilitate scalable annotation and analysis, the authors propose CAPO, an automatic annotation framework leveraging large language models to generate taxonomy-based labels. Experiments demonstrate that CAPO outperforms baseline annotation methods by achieving higher agreement with human expert judgments. Overall, this combined approach of taxonomy, dataset, and CAPO presents a principled and scalable methodology for interpreting, analyzing, and ultimately advancing the reasoning capabilities of LRMs through insights grounded in human cognitive science.
arXiv:2512.00729v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large reasoning models (LRMs) have garnered significant attention from researchers owing to their exceptional capability in addressing complex tasks. Motivated by the observed human-like behaviors in their reasoning processes, this paper introduces a comprehensive taxonomy to characterize atomic reasoning steps and probe the ``psyche'' of LRM intelligence. Specifically, it comprises five groups and seventeen categories derived from human mental processes, thereby grounding the understanding of LRMs in an interdisciplinary perspective. The taxonomy is then applied for an in-depth understanding of current LRMs, resulting in a distinct labeled dataset that comprises 277,534 atomic reasoning steps. Using this resource, we analyze contemporary LRMs and distill several actionable takeaways for improving training and post-training of reasoning models. Notably, our analysis reveals that prevailing post-answer ``double-checks'' (self-monitoring evaluations) are largely superficial and rarely yield substantive revisions. Thus, incentivizing comprehensive multi-step reflection, rather than simple self-monitoring, may offer a more effective path forward. To complement the taxonomy, an automatic annotation framework, named CAPO, is proposed to leverage large language models (LLMs) for generating the taxonomy-based annotations. Experimental results demonstrate that CAPO achieves higher consistency with human experts compared to baselines, facilitating a scalable and comprehensive analysis of LRMs from a human cognitive perspective. Together, the taxonomy, CAPO, and the derived insights provide a principled, scalable path toward understanding and advancing LRM reasoning.

item.title: MPR-GUI: Benchmarking and Enhancing Multilingual Perception and Reasoning in GUI Agents
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Vision-Language Models, multilingual GUI, perception and reasoning, GUI-XLI, fine-grained benchmark

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of evaluating and improving the performance of Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) on Graphical User Interface (GUI) tasks in multilingual settings. While LVLMs have shown strong perception and reasoning (P&R) capabilities on English GUI tasks, their effectiveness in non-English languages has been largely unexplored, limiting their broader applicability. To fill this gap, the authors introduce MPR-GUI-Bench, a multilingual fine-grained benchmark designed to assess GUI agents' P&R skills, including detailed aspects such as widget functions and spatial relationships between elements. Evaluations reveal a significant performance drop for LVLMs in non-English compared to English settings. To mitigate this, the paper proposes GUI-XLI, a cross-lingual intervention approach that modifies hidden states at P&R-related layers within the model to reduce disparities observed in the latent space among different languages. GUI-XLI builds on prior findings that hidden states vary considerably with language inputs. Experimental results demonstrate that GUI-XLI improves multilingual P&R performance of GUI agents by an average of 6.5%, suggesting its effectiveness in enhancing LVLMs for multilingual GUI understanding and reasoning tasks. This work pioneers fine-grained analysis and intervention strategies for multilingual GUI applications of LVLMs.
arXiv:2512.00756v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the advancement of computational resources, Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) exhibit impressive Perception and Reasoning (P&R) performance on Graphical User Interface (GUI) tasks. However, although they demonstrate strong P&R capabilities in English GUI scenarios, their performance in multilingual settings has received little attention, which limits their global applications. Moreover, existing studies on GUI tasks lack fine-grained analyses, including widget functions and elements' spatial relationships, which are fundamental for more targeted improvements. To tackle these issues, we propose MPR-GUI-Bench, a Multilingual fine-grained Perception and Reasoning GUI Benchmark to evaluate GUI agents' P&R capabilities. Evaluation results demonstrate that LVLMs exhibit significantly worse P&R performance in non-English languages than in English. To address these gaps, we propose GUI-XLI, a GUI Cross-Lingual Intervention method that applies interventions to the hidden states at P&R capability-related layers to mitigate the gaps between English and other languages, building on previous research showing that the hidden states of different language inputs exhibit significant differences in the latent space. Experimental results indicate that our method improves GUI agents' multilingual P&R capability by 6.5% on average.

item.title: BioPro: On Difference-Aware Gender Fairness for Vision-Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Gender bias, Vision-Language Models, selective debiasing, BioPro, bias mitigation

Summary:

1. The paper addresses social biases, particularly gender bias, present in Vision-Language Models (VLMs) that arise from their training data.

2. Existing fairness interventions often treat all demographic groups uniformly without distinguishing between situations that require neutrality and those where group-specific attributes should be preserved.

3. The authors extend the concept of difference-aware fairness, previously studied in text-only models, to multimodal tasks such as image captioning and text-to-image generation to handle gender bias more effectively.

4. They propose a novel, training-free framework called BioPro (Bias Orthogonal Projection), which identifies a low-dimensional gender-variation subspace via counterfactual embeddings and applies orthogonal projection to selectively neutralize unwanted gender-related information in neutral contexts while maintaining gender-specific details when appropriate.

5. Experimental results demonstrate that BioPro reduces gender bias without compromising gender faithfulness in explicit contexts and generalizes well to other continuous bias variables like scene brightness, showcasing its broader applicability in bias mitigation within VLMs.
arXiv:2512.00807v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) inherit significant social biases from their training data, notably in gender representation. Current fairness interventions often adopt a difference-unaware perspective that enforces uniform treatment across demographic groups. These approaches, however, fail to distinguish between contexts where neutrality is required and those where group-specific attributes are legitimate and must be preserved. Building upon recent advances in difference-aware fairness for text-only models, we extend this concept to the multimodal domain and formalize the problem of difference-aware gender fairness for image captioning and text-to-image generation. We advocate for selective debiasing, which aims to mitigate unwanted bias in neutral contexts while preserving valid distinctions in explicit ones. To achieve this, we propose BioPro (Bias Orthogonal Projection), an entirely training-free framework. BioPro identifies a low-dimensional gender-variation subspace through counterfactual embeddings and applies projection to selectively neutralize gender-related information. Experiments show that BioPro effectively reduces gender bias in neutral cases while maintaining gender faithfulness in explicit ones, thus providing a promising direction toward achieving selective fairness in VLMs. Beyond gender bias, we further demonstrate that BioPro can effectively generalize to continuous bias variables, such as scene brightness, highlighting its broader applicability.

item.title: Med-CMR: A Fine-Grained Benchmark Integrating Visual Evidence and Clinical Logic for Medical Complex Multimodal Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
MLLMs, Medical Reasoning, Visual Understanding, Benchmark, GPT-5

Summary:

1) This work introduces Med-CMR, a fine-grained benchmark designed to evaluate Medical Complex Multimodal Reasoning capabilities of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in clinical workflows.
2) Med-CMR decomposes medical multimodal reasoning into detailed visual understanding tasks—such as small-object detection, fine-detail discrimination, and spatial understanding—and multi-step reasoning scenarios including temporal prediction, causal reasoning, long-tail generalization, and multi-source integration.
3) The benchmark offers broad and high-quality data coverage featuring 20,653 Visual Question Answering (VQA) pairs across 11 organ systems and 12 imaging modalities, validated through a rigorous two-stage expert and model-assisted review ensuring clinical authenticity.
4) An evaluation of 18 state-of-the-art MLLMs on Med-CMR demonstrated that GPT-5 leads the commercial models with 57.81% accuracy on multiple-choice questions and a 48.70 open-ended score, outperforming Gemini 2.5 Pro and the best open-source model Qwen3-VL-235B-A22B.
5) Despite this, specialized medical MLLMs do not consistently outperform strong general models, with long-tail case generalization remaining the main challenge. Med-CMR thus provides a stringent assessment tool for visual-reasoning integration and rare-case robustness in medical MLLMs, shaping future clinical AI system development.
arXiv:2512.00818v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: MLLMs MLLMs are beginning to appear in clinical workflows, but their ability to perform complex medical reasoning remains unclear. We present Med-CMR, a fine-grained Medical Complex Multimodal Reasoning benchmark. Med-CMR distinguishes from existing counterparts by three core features: 1) Systematic capability decomposition, splitting medical multimodal reasoning into fine-grained visual understanding and multi-step reasoning to enable targeted evaluation; 2) Challenging task design, with visual understanding across three key dimensions (small-object detection, fine-detail discrimination, spatial understanding) and reasoning covering four clinically relevant scenarios (temporal prediction, causal reasoning, long-tail generalization, multi-source integration); 3) Broad, high-quality data coverage, comprising 20,653 Visual Question Answering (VQA) pairs spanning 11 organ systems and 12 imaging modalities, validated via a rigorous two-stage (human expert + model-assisted) review to ensure clinical authenticity. We evaluate 18 state-of-the-art MLLMs with Med-CMR, revealing GPT-5 as the top-performing commercial model: 57.81 accuracy on multiple-choice questions (MCQs) and a 48.70 open-ended score, outperforming Gemini 2.5 Pro (49.87 MCQ accuracy, 45.98 open-ended score) and leading open-source model Qwen3-VL-235B-A22B (49.34 MCQ accuracy, 42.62 open-ended score). However, specialized medical MLLMs do not reliably outperform strong general models, and long-tail generalization emerges as the dominant failure mode. Med-CMR thus provides a stress test for visual-reasoning integration and rare-case robustness in medical MLLMs, and a rigorous yardstick for future clinical systems.

item.title: SemAgent: Semantic-Driven Agentic AI Empowered Trajectory Prediction in Vehicular Networks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: trajectory prediction, semantic communication, Agentic AI, V2X networks, feature extraction

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges of efficient information exchange and reliable contextual reasoning in vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks, focusing on improving trajectory prediction under communication constraints. First, it identifies the limitations of conventional communication schemes, which suffer from high transmission overhead and latency, and notes that existing trajectory prediction models often lack environmental perception and logical inference. Second, it proposes a novel trajectory prediction framework that integrates semantic communication with Agentic AI to overcome these issues and enhance the prediction accuracy in vehicular environments. Third, the framework differentiates between vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) and vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication: in V2I, a feature-extraction agent at the roadside unit (RSU) compacts historical trajectory data and a semantic-analysis agent extracts semantic insights, both transmitted to vehicles for improved predictions; in V2V, each vehicle performs local feature extraction and semantic analysis while incorporating neighbors’ predicted trajectories for joint reasoning. Finally, extensive experiments under various communication conditions show that the proposed method significantly outperforms baseline approaches, achieving up to a 47.5% improvement in prediction accuracy, particularly in low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) scenarios, demonstrating its robustness and practical value for intelligent transportation systems.
arXiv:2512.00834v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Efficient information exchange and reliable contextual reasoning are essential for vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks. Conventional communication schemes often incur significant transmission overhead and latency, while existing trajectory prediction models generally lack environmental perception and logical inference capabilities. This paper presents a trajectory prediction framework that integrates semantic communication with Agentic AI to enhance predictive performance in vehicular environments. In vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication, a feature-extraction agent at the Roadside Unit (RSU) derives compact representations from historical vehicle trajectories, followed by semantic reasoning performed by a semantic-analysis agent. The RSU then transmits both feature representations and semantic insights to the target vehicle via semantic communication, enabling the vehicle to predict future trajectories by combining received semantics with its own historical data. In vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication, each vehicle performs local feature extraction and semantic analysis while receiving predicted trajectories from neighboring vehicles, and jointly utilizes this information for its own trajectory prediction. Extensive experiments across diverse communication conditions demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms baseline schemes, achieving up to a 47.5% improvement in prediction accuracy under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions.

item.title: Assessing model error in counterfactual worlds
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: counterfactual scenario modeling, scenario evaluation, model miscalibration, counterfactual error estimation, decision making

Summary:

This article addresses the challenge of evaluating counterfactual scenario modeling, which involves asking "what would happen if?" questions commonly used in planning and decision making. It highlights that discrepancies between scenario projections and actual outcomes arise from two main sources: scenario deviation and model miscalibration. The authors emphasize that model miscalibration is the more critical factor when assessing the value of models in decision-making processes. However, estimating model error in unobserved, counterfactual scenarios poses a unique challenge. To tackle this, the paper presents and compares three different approaches for estimating counterfactual error. A simulation experiment is used to demonstrate the advantages and drawbacks of each method. Based on these findings, the authors provide practical recommendations for effectively estimating counterfactual error. Finally, the article discusses key elements of scenario design necessary to make scenario projections evaluable, ensuring that future scenario modeling can be retrospectively assessed to improve reliability and usefulness in planning contexts.
arXiv:2512.00836v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Counterfactual scenario modeling exercises that ask "what would happen if?" are one of the most common ways we plan for the future. Despite their ubiquity in planning and decision making, scenario projections are rarely evaluated retrospectively. Differences between projections and observations come from two sources: scenario deviation and model miscalibration. We argue the latter is most important for assessing the value of models in decision making, but requires estimating model error in counterfactual worlds. Here we present and contrast three approaches for estimating this error, and demonstrate the benefits and limitations of each in a simulation experiment. We provide recommendations for the estimation of counterfactual error and discuss the components of scenario design that are required to make scenario projections evaluable.

item.title: ARCADIA: Scalable Causal Discovery for Corporate Bankruptcy Analysis Using Agentic AI
item.content:encoded:
ARCADIA, causal discovery, large language models, DAG refinement, explainable AI

Summary:

This paper presents ARCADIA, an innovative AI framework designed for causal discovery that uniquely combines large language model (LLM) reasoning with traditional statistical diagnostics to build causally valid and temporally consistent structures. Unlike conventional causal inference algorithms, ARCADIA employs an iterative process where candidate Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) are refined through constraint-guided prompting and continuous feedback on causal validity. This approach enhances stability and interpretability in the resulting causal models, which is critically important in high-stakes, real-world applications. The framework’s effectiveness is demonstrated through experiments using corporate bankruptcy data, where ARCADIA outperforms established methods such as NOTEARS, GOLEM, and DirectLiNGAM by generating more reliable and robust causal graphs. Additionally, ARCADIA offers a fully explainable and intervention-ready pipeline, making it suitable for practical deployment where transparency and actionability are vital. Fundamentally, this work advances the field of AI by showcasing how agentic LLMs can autonomously engage in scientific modeling and structured causal inference, highlighting a new paradigm where language models play an active role in generating and validating causal knowledge.
arXiv:2512.00839v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper introduces ARCADIA, an agentic AI framework for causal discovery that integrates large-language-model reasoning with statistical diagnostics to construct valid, temporally coherent causal structures. Unlike traditional algorithms, ARCADIA iteratively refines candidate DAGs through constraint-guided prompting and causal-validity feedback, leading to stable and interpretable models for real-world high-stakes domains. Experiments on corporate bankruptcy data show that ARCADIA produces more reliable causal graphs than NOTEARS, GOLEM, and DirectLiNGAM while offering a fully explainable, intervention-ready pipeline. The framework advances AI by demonstrating how agentic LLMs can participate in autonomous scientific modeling and structured causal inference.

item.title: One Swallow Does Not Make a Summer: Understanding Semantic Structures in Embedding Spaces
item.content:encoded:
Embedding spaces, Semantic Field Subspace, SAFARI algorithm, Semantic Shift, hierarchical semantic structures

Summary:

1. The paper introduces the Semantic Field Subspace (SFS), a novel representation that preserves geometric properties and captures local semantic neighborhoods within high-dimensional embedding spaces. 2. To analyze these structures, the authors develop SAFARI (SemAntic Field subspAce deteRmInation), an unsupervised and modality-agnostic algorithm that uncovers hierarchical semantic structures by leveraging a new metric called Semantic Shift, which measures semantic evolution across SFSes. 3. To address computational inefficiency, the authors propose an efficient approximation for Semantic Shift, replacing costly singular value decomposition (SVD) with a faster method that achieves 15 to 30 times speedup while maintaining average errors below 0.01. 4. The framework is evaluated on six diverse, real-world datasets containing both text and images, demonstrating that SFS-based models outperform standard classifiers in classification tasks and in more nuanced areas such as political bias detection. 5. Overall, this work provides a unified, scalable approach for structuring and interpreting embedding spaces, enhancing semantic understanding with improved interpretability and computational efficiency.
arXiv:2512.00852v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Embedding spaces are fundamental to modern AI, translating raw data into high-dimensional vectors that encode rich semantic relationships. Yet, their internal structures remain opaque, with existing approaches often sacrificing semantic coherence for structural regularity or incurring high computational overhead to improve interpretability. To address these challenges, we introduce the Semantic Field Subspace (SFS), a geometry-preserving, context-aware representation that captures local semantic neighborhoods within the embedding space. We also propose SAFARI (SemAntic Field subspAce deteRmInation), an unsupervised, modality-agnostic algorithm that uncovers hierarchical semantic structures using a novel metric called Semantic Shift, which quantifies how semantics evolve as SFSes evolve. To ensure scalability, we develop an efficient approximation of Semantic Shift that replaces costly SVD computations, achieving a 15~30x speedup with average errors below 0.01. Extensive evaluations across six real-world text and image datasets show that SFSes outperform standard classifiers not only in classification but also in nuanced tasks such as political bias detection, while SAFARI consistently reveals interpretable and generalizable semantic hierarchies. This work presents a unified framework for structuring, analyzing, and scaling semantic understanding in embedding spaces.

item.title: Hybrid-DMKG: A Hybrid Reasoning Framework over Dynamic Multimodal Knowledge Graphs for Multimodal Multihop QA with Knowledge Editing
item.content:encoded:
Multimodal Knowledge Editing, Multihop Question Answering, Dynamic Multimodal Knowledge Graph, Hybrid Reasoning, Robustness

Summary:

Multimodal Knowledge Editing (MKE) extends traditional knowledge editing by involving both textual and visual data. Existing benchmarks overlook intermediate reasoning quality and robustness against visually rephrased inputs. To fill this gap, the authors propose MMQAKE, the first benchmark specifically designed for multimodal multihop question answering with a focus on knowledge editing. MMQAKE tests a model’s ability to reason over 2-5 step factual chains that incorporate both images and text, evaluating both intermediate reasoning and robustness to visual rephrasing. Experiments reveal that current MKE methods struggle to consistently update and reason over these multimodal reasoning chains after knowledge edits. To address these shortcomings, the paper introduces Hybrid-DMKG, a hybrid reasoning framework using a dynamic multimodal knowledge graph (DMKG). This framework decomposes complex multimodal questions into sequential sub-questions using a large language model, employs a multimodal retrieval model to find updated facts, and infers answers via a hybrid reasoning module combining relation linking and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) using vision-language models. A decision module integrates evidence from both paths to select the most credible answer. Evaluation on MMQAKE demonstrates that Hybrid-DMKG significantly surpasses existing methods in accuracy and robustness following knowledge updates.
arXiv:2512.00881v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multimodal Knowledge Editing (MKE) extends traditional knowledge editing to settings involving both textual and visual modalities. However, existing MKE benchmarks primarily assess final answer correctness while neglecting the quality of intermediate reasoning and robustness to visually rephrased inputs. To address this limitation, we introduce MMQAKE, the first benchmark for multimodal multihop question answering with knowledge editing. MMQAKE evaluates (1) a model's ability to reason over 2-5-hop factual chains that span both text and images, including performance at each intermediate step, and (2) robustness to visually rephrased inputs in multihop questions. Our evaluation shows that current MKE methods often struggle to consistently update and reason over multimodal reasoning chains after knowledge edits. To overcome these challenges, we propose Hybrid-DMKG, a hybrid reasoning framework built on a dynamic multimodal knowledge graph (DMKG) to enable accurate multihop reasoning over updated multimodal knowledge. Hybrid-DMKG first uses a large language model to decompose multimodal multihop questions into sequential sub-questions, then applies a multimodal retrieval model to locate updated facts by jointly encoding each sub-question with candidate entities and their associated images. For answer inference, a hybrid reasoning module operates over the DMKG via two parallel paths: (1) relation linking prediction, and (2) RAG reasoning with large vision-language models. A decision module aggregates evidence from both paths to select the most credible answer. Experimental results on MMQAKE show that Hybrid-DMKG significantly outperforms existing MKE approaches, achieving higher accuracy and improved robustness to knowledge updates.

item.title: Minimal neuron ablation triggers catastrophic collapse in the language core of Large Vision-Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Vision-Language Models, critical neurons, consistent activation, catastrophic collapse, model robustness

Summary: This paper investigates the structural vulnerabilities of Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs), focusing on identifying critical neurons whose removal triggers catastrophic performance collapse. The authors introduce CAN, a novel method to detect Consistently Activated Neurons and locate these critical neurons through progressive masking techniques. Their experiments, conducted on LLaVA-1.5-7b-hf and InstructBLIP-Vicuna-7b models, reveal that masking a very small subset of neurons—sometimes as few as four—within the language model’s feed-forward networks is sufficient to cause a catastrophic collapse in model performance. Importantly, these critical neurons are mainly found in the language model components rather than the vision modules. Further analysis shows that the down-projection layer within the language model is particularly vulnerable. The collapse process exhibits a two-stage pattern: an initial phase of expressive degradation followed by an abrupt and complete failure of the model. These findings highlight key weaknesses in LVLMs and offer important insights for future research focused on improving model robustness and safety, emphasizing the need to consider internal neuron-level vulnerabilities during model design and evaluation.
arXiv:2512.00918v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have shown impressive multimodal understanding capabilities, yet their robustness is poorly understood. In this paper, we investigate the structural vulnerabilities of LVLMs to identify any critical neurons whose removal triggers catastrophic collapse. In this context, we propose CAN, a method to detect Consistently Activated Neurons and to locate critical neurons by progressive masking. Experiments on LLaVA-1.5-7b-hf and InstructBLIP-Vicuna-7b reveal that masking only a tiny portion of the language model's feed-forward networks (just as few as four neurons in extreme cases) suffices to trigger catastrophic collapse. Notably, critical neurons are predominantly localized in the language model rather than in the vision components, and the down-projection layer is a particularly vulnerable structure. We also observe a consistent two-stage collapse pattern: initial expressive degradation followed by sudden, complete collapse. Our findings provide important insights for safety research in LVLMs.

item.title: Integrating Causal Foundation Model in Prescriptive Maintenance Framework for Optimizing Production Line OEE
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: prescriptive maintenance, causal machine learning, predictive models, intervention ranking, manufacturing KPIs

Summary:

This paper addresses the critical limitation in transitioning to prescriptive maintenance within manufacturing, focusing on the reliance of current predictive models on spurious correlations rather than true causal drivers of failure. It highlights the challenge that while failures can be predicted, understanding their root causes remains elusive, limiting the effectiveness of corrective actions.
